I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
Housing Construction Savings Bank of Kazakhstan (HCSBK), to be guaranteed by the Republic 
of Kazakhstan, for the Promoting Gender Equality in Housing Finance Project. The report also 
describes the proposed technical assistance (TA) for Supporting the Promoting Gender Equality 
in  Housing  Finance  Project,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA. 
 
2. 
The  proposed  financial  intermediation  loan  (FIL)  of  up  to  $100  million  equivalent  will 
provide local currency credit to promote the provision of affordable residential mortgage loans to 
women borrowers in primarily rural areas of Kazakhstan. The TA will strengthen credit origination 
and product offerings of HCSBK to better serve its existing and new women borrowers. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Constraints in the Kazakhstan housing market. As of 1 January 2018, the total housing 
stock in Kazakhstan consisted of 5,129,743 housing units, of which 66.4% were located in urban 
areas and 33.6% in rural areas. In 2007–2018, the overall floor space per capita improved from 
17.5 square meters (m2) to 21.4 m2 (an increase of 22% per annum).1 However, despite these 
improvements, demand for housing remains high because of the following factors: 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

Rising income. Kazakhstan benefited from higher prices for its commodity exports 
during a series of resource booms.  In 2000-2019, country’s  per capita income 
has more than quintupled during the same period, from $1,349 to $8,840.2 
Household growth. The number of households in Kazakhstan increased from 4.6 
million in 2013 to more than 5.0 million in 2017 as the total population grew while 
the  average  household  size  remained  unchanged.  The  growth  was  particularly 
prominent in cities because of ongoing urbanization. 
Ongoing urbanization. During 1996–2019, the urban population increased by 1.5 
million,  or  19.5%,  to  10.7  million  persons  (58.1%  of  the  total  population).  This 
migration from rural to urban areas is expected to continue. 
Inadequate  housing  stock.  Almost  half  of  the  current  housing  stock  was  built 
prior  to  1980  and  has  not  been  substantially  upgraded  or  modernized.  Further, 
about 10% of all families in Kazakhstan live in one-room accommodation and there 
is an unmet demand for larger housing units. The average floor area per capita of 
21.4 m2 (in 2017) is well below international standards.3 In southern Kazakhstan, 
the available housing space is even smaller, averaging 18 m2 per person. 

 
Low supply of affordable housing with adequate building standards. Although most 
4. 
of the households in Kazakhstan live in their own housing units, affordable quality housing is in 
low supply, since real house prices rose almost sixfold from 2001 to 2016, for both newly built 

                                                
1   Government of Kazakhstan, Ministry of National Economy, Statistics Committee. 2017. Report on the housing stock 

of Kazakhstan. Astana.  

2  Although  per  capita  income  has  declined  in  2016-2018  stemming  from  the  recent  financial  crisis  and  resulting 

currency devaluation, it was still relatively high at $8,840 as of 2018. 

3  Average floor area per capita is 30 m2–35 m2 per person in low-income countries and 45 m2–50 m2 per person in 
upper  middle-income  countries.  R.  Anker  and  M.  Anker.  2017.  Living  Wages  Around  the  World:  Manual  for 
Measurement. Cheltenham, United Kingdom: Edward Elgar Publishing. Chapter 5. 

 

 

 and  existing  dwellings.4 The  2016  economic  slowdown  has  negatively  affected  the  prices  and 
sales volumes of large, expensive housing units, while the demand for modest housing has not 
slowed down, particularly in the regions located outside the major cities. Although the number of 
new  housing  units  increased  by  67%  during  2007–2017  to  cover  11.2  million  m2  in  2017,  this 
growth accounted for only 3.3% of the total housing stock.5 Kazakhstan’s rental market is  also 
underdeveloped because of a high homeownership rate: 97% of all residents live in a housing 
unit owned by a household member (however there are cases where 2-3 families live in the same 
housing unit) and only 3% rent their current housing units. 
 
5. 
Expensive housing. Prior to the 2008–2009 crisis, the real estate market in Kazakhstan 
overheated as evidenced by an extremely high housing affordability index of 28.4 years in 2007.6 
After  the  2008  market  crash,  property  prices  dropped,  improving  affordability.  Since  2011,  the 
housing affordability index has stabilized at about 13 years for new real estate, but for existing 
housing it has deteriorated from 9.7 years to 10.6 years.7 As a result, the real estate market in 
Kazakhstan  remains  expensive  by  international  standards:  it  currently  ranks  as  the  13th  most 
expensive country in the world, according to an international property prices index—well ahead 
of neighboring countries such as Azerbaijan (23rd), Georgia (25th), and the Russian Federation 
(28th).8 
 
6. 
Factors  for  the  low  housing  affordability  in  Kazakhstan.  The  main  reasons  are  (i) 
sharp devaluation of the local currency in 2014 and 2015, and continued depreciation of the tenge 
as compared with the United States dollar since 2017 which has substantially increased the cost 
of  house  construction  since  much  of  the  raw  material  is  imported;  (ii)  persistent  inflationary 
pressures,  as  evidenced  by  the  consumer  price  index  reaching  5.3%  in  May  2019;  (iii)  a 
concurrent increase in housing prices, which rose by 14% for primary market housing units and 
18% for secondary market housing units in 2018; (iv) declining purchasing power of consumer 
wages since 2015; and (v) inadequate supply of mortgage financing by commercial banks, which 
experienced  high  levels  of  nonperforming  loans  (NPLs)  during  the  last  two  financial  crises  in 
Kazakhstan because of lending to non-creditworthy borrowers and issuing United States dollar-
denominated mortgage loans to borrowers whose earnings were in tenge.9 
 
7. 
Shallow  mortgage  finance  sector.  The  mortgage  finance  sector  in  Kazakhstan  is 
underdeveloped, with mortgage loans comprising 2.2% of gross domestic product in 2018.10 This 
level is substantially lower than in neighboring countries, e.g., 12.1% in Georgia and 5.6% in the 
Russian  Federation.  Similarly,  residential  mortgage  loans  amounted  to  only  T1.4  billion, 
representing 11% of the total loan portfolio of Kazakhstan’s banks as of 31 December 201811—
again, a very modest level when compared with other countries in the region such as Georgia 

                                                
4  W. Seitz. 2018. Urbanization in Kazakhstan. Desirable Cities, Unaffordable Housing, and the Missing Rental Market. 

Poverty and Equity Global Practice Working Paper Series. No. 160. Washington, DC: World Bank. 

5  Government of Kazakhstan, Ministry of National Economy, Statistics Committee. 2017. Report on the housing stock 

of Kazakhstan. Astana.  

6  The housing affordability index indicates the number of years that a family of three (two adults and one child with two 

salaries) should work to afford the down payment for a 54 m2 apartment. 

7  Samruk-Kazyna. 2016. Kazakhstan’s Real Estate Market. Astana.  
8  Numbeo. Property Prices Index for Country 2019 (accessed 1 July 2019). 
9  Ranking.kz. 2017. Kazakhstan housing market assessment. Almaty. 
10 Government of Kazakhstan, Ministry of National Economy, Statistics Committee. Dynamics of basic socio-economic 

indicators of the Republic of Kazakhstan (accessed 3 July 2019). 

11 National Bank of Kazakhstan. 2019. Report of current condition of the banking sector (as of 1 January 2019). Almaty. 
 

2 

 

 3 

(24.5%) or the Russian Federation (42.4%).12 In terms of loan currency, 97.2% of all outstanding 
mortgages  were  in  tenge  as  of  April  2019.  In  addition  to  being  underdeveloped,  mortgages  in 
Kazakhstan  are  also  expensive  by  international  standards,  with  average  mortgage  payments 
comprising 203% of net disposable family income in 2019, well above the 164% in Georgia or 
150% in the Russian Federation (footnote 12). 
 
8. 
Low access to mortgage finance for women, in particular in rural areas. Apart from 
government-led social housing programs, the present mortgage lending market in Kazakhstan is 
mainly geared toward higher-income groups. Although 4.4 million out of the 9.1 million women in 
Kazakhstan (51% of the total population) are considered to be economically active, they face a 
significant gender pay gap of 32%.13 Furthermore, 50.9% of all Kazakh households are headed 
by a woman and 15.1% are single mothers (over twice that of single fathers).14 However, women, 
more  often  than  men,  face  lower  access  to  affordable  mortgage  finance  (although  women’s 
educational levels in Kazakhstan are at par or higher than those of men) due to major constraints 
such as accessing bank financial services, prolonged and complicated procedures for commercial 
loan approval, and excessive paperwork and terms and conditions. In rural areas, potential female 
borrowers are even more disadvantaged in accessing mortgage financing, as the majority of rural 
women are occupied in informal self-employed activities (such as the food, agriculture, and trade 
industries).  With  lower  income  levels,  they  face  higher  collateral  requirements  for  obtaining 
mortgage loans. Enabling such female borrowers to acquire a housing unit will help strengthen 
their access to credit given that real estate remains a preferred type of collateral for most banks. 
This is particularly relevant for homebound and small business women entrepreneurs (prevalent 
in rural areas) who face challenges in accessing finance because of the informal and/or irregular 
nature of their income and their higher credit risk categorization by banks. 
 
9. 
Government’s strategy. Since 2005, the Government of Kazakhstan has initiated various 
programs to improve access to housing, including housing rental schemes, savings plans, interest 
rate subsidies, and support to private housing developers. The first such program is the 2017–
2021 Nurly Zher housing development program, which was approved on 31 December 2016 with 
a budget of T800 billion.15 More recently, the government launched the 7-20-25 housing program, 
which aims to provide housing to 1.5 million people by the end of 2020. The program is the largest 
government housing initiative to date, with an indicative financing envelope of T1.0 trillion.16 
 
10. 
Unaffordable  housing  for  a  growing  number  of  the  population.  Despite  the 
achievements made under these state housing programs, owning a modern and well-built housing 
unit  remains  unaffordable  for  many  households,  in  particular  young  families  and  young 
professionals. According to the Ministry of National Economy, about 71.4% of the economically 
active  population  could  not  afford  to  buy  a  housing  unit.  As  a  consequence,  about  2.5  million 
people in Kazakhstan are currently on the various wait lists for housing and the number continues 
to grow.17 The sharp local currency devaluation in 2015 severely affected the ability of households

Network.

comparative

data 

2019. 

14 EuroPlus Consulting and Management Report. 2017. Gender Study for Central Asia. Astana. 
15 Government of Kazakhstan. 2015. The State Program of Infrastructure Development Nurly Zhol for 2015–2019. Nur-

16 Government of Kazakhstan. 2018.7-20-25 State mortgage program. Astana. 
17 United  Nations  Economic  Commission  for  Europe.  2018.  Country  Profiles  on  the  Housing  Sector:  Republic  of 

by gender. Astana.  

Sultan. 

Kazakhstan. Geneva. 

 

 to save for a down payment to obtain a mortgage loan, and it increased the debt burden because 
of the weakened purchasing power of consumer wages. 
 
11. 
Consistency  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Strategy  2030  and  country 
strategy.  The  proposed  intervention  is  aligned  with  the  following  key  operational  priorities  of 
Strategy  2030  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB):  (i)  increasing  support  for  banks  to  help 
improve  their  capacity,  quality,  and  reach,  particularly  for  low-income  populations,  to  address 
remaining  poverty  and  reduce  inequalities;  (ii)  promoting  rural  development;  (iii)  improving 
progress  in gender  equality  through financial  inclusion;  and  (iv)  supporting  innovative  financial 
products.18 The project is also consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Kazakhstan, 
2017–2021,  which  supports  inclusive  economic  growth  through  infrastructure  development, 
financial  inclusion,  and  enhanced  gender  equity. 19  The  loan  is  included  in  ADB’s  country 
operations business plan, 2019–2021.20 Finally, the ADB loan is aligned with the core objectives 
and goals of the government, in particular, with the Nurly Zher program (para. 9). 
 
12. 
ADB’s  sector  experience  and  assistance  program.  While  ADB  has  no  previous 
experience in the housing finance sector in Kazakhstan,21 the bank has relevant experience in 
designing and implementing financial intermediary interventions with substantial gender elements 
in the country. In 2010, ADB approved the $500 million multitranche financing facility to the Damu 
Entrepreneurship  Development  Fund  (Damu),  which    was  categorized  as  effective  gender 
mainstreaming.22 The project proved that gender action plans (GAPs) are an effective instrument 
to promote gender equality outcomes and influence government counterparts to build ownership 
during implementation. 23 In 2016, ADB approved an FIL of $200 million equivalent to Damu to 
support  the  resilience  of  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (MSMEs).24 The  project, 
which  is  ongoing,  provides  local  currency  credit  to  sustain  operations  of,  and  employment  by, 
MSMEs and helped strengthen the credit origination and management of selected participating 
financial  institutions  to  better  serve  their  MSME  clients.  It  aims  to  fund  at  least  $50  million 
equivalent to businesses owned by women, with one-third of the total number of sub-borrowers 
being women. 
 
13. 
Development  partner  coordination.  The  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development,  the  International  Finance  Corporation,  the  United  Nations,  and  the  World  Bank 
support  the  housing  sector  and  housing  finance  in  Kazakhstan  through  various  initiatives  and 
programs, which include (i) economic, social, and environmental assessments of the country’s 
housing  policies  and  programs;  (ii)  reviews  of  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  and 

                                                
18 ADB.  2018.  Strategy  2030.  Achieving  a  Prosperous,  Inclusive,  Resilient,  and  Sustainable  Asia  and  the  Pacific. 

Manila. 

19 ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Kazakhstan, 2017–2021—Promoting Economic Diversification, Inclusive 

Development, and Sustainable Growth. Manila. 

20 ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Kazakhstan, 2019–2021. Manila. 
21 However, ADB has substantial experience in implementing housing finance projects in many developing member 
countries,  including  Armenia, India,  Indonesia,  Mongolia,  Sri  Lanka,  Uzbekistan,  and  Viet  Nam. Lessons  learned 
from  these  interventions  include  the  following:  (i)  having  a  strong  implementing  agency  with  substantial  lending 
experience in the sector is crucial; (ii) targeting lower-income households can strengthen the development impact of 
the  project;  (iii)  having  transparent  and  fair  eligibility  criteria  for  beneficiary  selection  is  critical;  and  (iv)  using 
subsidies, in particular, interest rate subsidies, should ideally be avoided, as they crowd out the private sector. 

22  ADB.  2010.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Multitranche 
Financing Facility to the Republic of Kazakhstan for the Small and Medium Enterprise Investment Program. Manila. 

23  ADB. 2018. Kazakhstan Country Gender Assessment. Manila. 
24  ADB.  2016.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Loan  and 
Administration of Technical Assistance Grant to the Damu Entrepreneurship Development Fund for the Supporting 
Resilience  of  Micro,  Small,  and  Medium-Sized  Enterprises  Finance  Project  (Guaranteed  by  the  Republic  of 
Kazakhstan). Manila. 

4 

 

 5 

implementing  agencies  in the  housing finance  sector;  (iii)  business  development  services;  and 
(iv)  assistance  in  improving  the  lending  technologies  and  loan  products  of  some  of  the  banks 
involved  in  housing  finance.  ADB  closely  coordinates  with  these  institutions  to  avoid  any 
duplication  of  efforts  and  build  on  the  lessons  learned  and  achievements  made  by  the  other 
developments  partners.  For  instance,  the  proposed  ADB  intervention  takes  into  account  the 
recommendations  made  by  a  recent  International  Finance  Corporation  review  of  HCSBK’s 
operations, which suggested that HCSBK should (i) diversify its product range; (ii) introduce more 
commercially  oriented  mortgage  lending  instruments;  (iii)  diversify  its  funding  sources;  (iv) 
enhance its customer focus by analyzing consumer trends and preferences; and (v) expand its 
client base by focusing on self-employed persons located in rural areas, of which women account 
for more than 60%. 
 
HCSBK’s  mandate and market share. HCSBK is one of the major financial institutions 
14. 
supporting the development of the mortgage finance market in the country and is the main actor 
implementing government housing programs. Founded in 2003, it follows the German system of 
contractual savings for housing (the Bausparkassen model), wherein a housing loan is linked to 
a  savings  deposit.  HCSBK  typically  targets  the  low-  to  middle-income  borrower  segment  as 
evidenced by the fact that HCSBK’s average mortgage size is only T6.2 million. HCSBK provides 
services to about 12% of the economically active population, or about 1.05 million households. 
As of 31 December 2018, HCSBK had 1.30 million saving accounts, and it had issued 172,685 
loans  totaling  T1.14  trillion.  HCSBK  follows  prudent  onlending  practices  as  evidenced  by  its 
satisfactory financial standing and an NPL ratio of less than 1%. As of the end of 2018, HCSBK 
was  the  market  leader  in  mortgage  lending,  with  49%  market  share  in  the  banking  sector’s 
mortgage loan sector. Its 17 branches cover all regions of the country.25 
 
15. 
Housing  Construction  Savings  Bank  of  Kazakhstan’s  gender  focus.  The  bank 
maintains a strong focus on serving the needs of women, who comprised 55.5% of its borrowers 
at  the  end  of  2018.  However,  women  still  represent  a  largely  untapped  borrower  segment  in 
Kazakhstan  even  though  they  have  proven  to  be  more  disciplined  than  men  in  making  loan 
repayments: only 0.2% of all female borrowers have overdue payments of more than 90 days, 
compared with 0.4% for men. The main obstacle for HCSBK to expand its lending business to 
women  borrowers  is  the  shortage  of  long-term  funding.26 Further,  HCSBK  is  constrained  in  its 
growth  and  outreach  by  its  business  model,  which  stipulates  that  sub-borrowers  must  first 
accumulate savings that account for at least 50% of the cost of the housing unit before they can 
qualify for  a  low-interest  mortgage  loan from  the  bank. The financing  provided  by  ADB  will  be 
used by HCSBK to provide preliminary loans27 as an interim solution, as these loans will require 
the  accumulation  of  savings  of  only  15%–20%  before  a  mortgage  loan  can  be  granted  (i.e., 
women borrowers with a monthly household income below T200,000 will be granted lower down 

                                                
25 Overview  of  Housing  Construction  Savings  Bank  of  Kazakhstan’s  Operations  (accessible  from  the  list  of  linked 

documents in Appendix 2). 

26 As  a  systematically  important  financial  institution,  and  given  its  role  in  the  government’s  mandate  to  provide 
affordable housing, HCSBK has received support from the government in the form of subsidized funding and capital 
injections. However, in view of the precarious monetary position of the  government, this financial support can no 
longer be taken for granted. 

27 The preliminary loan product is available to depositors who have either accumulated 20% savings (in relation to their 
housing unit cost) or had deposited this amount up front. It has a loan ceiling of T5 million, has an interest rate of 
7%, has a loan term of 8 years, and is secured by the related real estate and savings deposit. The mortgagor pays 
only interest, with no amortization on the principal amount, and will continue to accumulate savings until 50% of the 
housing unit cost is saved and the 3-year minimum savings accumulation period has passed. Upon realization of 
these two requirements, savings will then be used to pay off half of the loan and the balance will be converted into a 
standard housing loan with a lower interest rate of 3.5%–5.0%. 

 

 payment requirements).28 Once the sub-borrowers have accumulated the required 50% savings 
rate, the preliminary loan will be converted into a regular housing loan with a lower interest rate. 
 
16. 
Demand for the proposed loan. The proposed loan from ADB to HCSBK will help the 
bank  address  the  unmet  demand  among  female  borrowers  for  longer-term,  fixed-rate,  local 
currency-denominated  mortgage  credit,  in  particular  in  the  rural  areas.  Of  Kazakhstan’s 
population, 9.1 million, or 51%, are women and 4.4 million are considered economically active. 
Over 60,000 of HCSBK’s borrowers are women, of which 64% are located outside of the largest 
two  cities  of  Nur-Sultan  and  Almaty.  Although  the  government  has  various  social  support 
programs for women in place,29 HCSBK currently has 30,000 female account holders who have 
accumulated  more  than  T2  million  (qualifying  them  for  a  preliminary  housing  loan  subject  to 
meeting other underwriting criteria) who have not yet received a housing loan.30 In April 2019  as 
part of the project preparatory activities, HCSBK call centers carried out a survey, which showed 
that 53% of the female depositors contacted expressed interest in receiving more information on 
the ADB-funded mortgage product, and 40% would consider applying for a mortgage loan with 
such a reduced savings requirement. 
 
B. 
 
17. 
The project is aligned with the following impact: gender equity promotion and sustainable 
economic  growth  achieved. 31  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  acquisition  and 
renovation of housing units by women increased.32 
 
18. 
The  project  will  deliver  the  following  outputs:  Output  1:  Long-term  affordable  mortgage 
financing  for  eligible  women  borrowers  made  available.  Through  the  ADB  loan  HCSBK  will 
provide  mortgage  loans  exclusively  targeted  at  women  borrowers  to  finance  at  least  3,000 
women;  Output  2:  Accessibility  to  HCSBK’s  lending  products  for  eligible  women  borrowers 
improved;  HCSBK  will  adopt  a  gender  policy  and  will  conduct  at  least  three  nationwide  public 
awareness campaigns on housing finance products for women; Output 3: Gender inclusiveness 
of the banking sector’s housing finance assessed. This output will be delivered by conducting a 
nationwide  study  on  women’s  access to housing  and finance  products    which    will  have  to  be 
endorsed by the government. 
 
19. 
ADB will provide HCSBK with an FIL of $100 million equivalent. HCSBK will use the tenge 
proceeds  from  ADB  to  offer  affordable  residential  mortgage  finance 33 exclusively  to  women 

Project Description 

                                                
28 At present, although HCSBK has ample liquidity on its balance sheet, most of these funds come from the savings 
that depositors accumulate in anticipation of receiving a traditional housing loan after a period of 3–5 years. By law, 
HCSBK is not allowed to use these funds to provide preliminary loans. Based on the HCSBK average loan size to 
women in 2018 of T8.7 million, it is expected that the ADB loan will fund at least 3,000 loans for the acquisition of 
housing units for a total of $80 million equivalent and 2,000 renovation loans for a total of $20 million equivalent. 
29 These  include  one-time  maternity  and  birth  allowances,  a  monthly  childcare  allowance,  and  an  unemployment 

allowance for nonworking mothers. 

30 HCSBK data. Preliminary loans, with a 20% down payment, would require deposit savings of T2.2 million and above 

(based on the average loan size to women in 2018 [footnote 30]). 

31 Government of Kazakhstan. 2017. Strategic Plan for the Development of Kazakhstan until 2025. Nur-Sultan. 
32 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
33 It is expected that the preliminary loans funded under the ADB project will be offered by HCSBK at the rate of 7%. 
HCSBK intends to use part of its equity capital to bring down the interest rate since the ADB loan is expected to be 
provided to the bank at an interest rate of about 9%–9.5% (depending on market conditions). The preliminary loans 
will have a down payment requirement as low as 15% (in the case of low-income female borrowers), which compares 
favorably  with  the  current  market  rates  for  commercial  mortgage  loans  of  15%–21%  with  a  minimum  30%  down 

6 

 

 

 7 

customers, each acting as the sole borrower and bearer of the legal title to a residential housing 
unit.34 The mortgage subloans provided by HCSBK will be used for the acquisition of residential 
housing units or the renovation of existing homes.35 A minimum of 60% of the proceeds from the 
ADB loan will be allocated to provide mortgage loans to female borrowers located in rural regions, 
i.e., those outside of the four large cities with the lowest poverty rates: Aktau, Almaty, Atyrau and 
Nur-Sultan.36 While the maximum monthly income level per household has been set at T320,000, 
at  least  20%  of  all  mortgage  loans  financed  by  the  ADB  loan  will  be  to  low-income  female 
borrowers with a monthly household income of less than T200,000.37 A price ceiling of T30 million 
will apply for housing units that can be financed under the ADB project, as well as a ceiling of 
T3.7 million for renovation loans. 
 
C. 

Value Added by ADB 

20. 

There will be five  ADB value additions associated with this project: 
(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

The  ADB  funding  will  provide  HCSBK  with  much-needed  liquidity  to  expand  its 
lending to women, particularly in rural areas. 
The loan will be the first external borrowing that HCSBK undertakes, as it has relied 
solely  on  government  funding  as  well  as  customer  saving  deposits.38 While  the 
ADB loan will be more expensive for HCSBK compared to its existing funding, as 
it will be based on market pricing principles, it will enable HCSBK to diversify its 
funding  sources,  develop  new  loan  products,  and  enhance  its  standing  and 
reputation in the mortgage finance sector of Kazakhstan as the premier housing 
finance institution. To this end, the loan will help HCSBK eventually graduate from 
relying on government support after it has undergone thorough due diligence from 
ADB. This will help prepare the bank for accessing pure commercial funding from 
private sector institutions and private sector arms of bilateral or multilateral banks, 
and raising financing from the international capital markets in the near future. 
This will be one of ADB’s first sovereign local currency interventions where funding 
has been raised through bonds issued by ADB in the domestic capital market. The 
ADB bonds will have a highly tailored structure adopted to mirror the terms of the 
underlying  loan  that  is  to  be  funded  with  the  proceeds.  It  is  expected  that  this 
innovative structure will have a substantial developmental impact on the promotion 
of the domestic bond market as it will enable some of the institutional investors, in 
particular  the  state-owned  pension  funds,  to  use  part  of  their  excess  liquidity  to 
invest in bond instruments with long tenors. It will also provide a new currency risk 
mitigation  solution  for  ADB’s  future  sovereign  and  quasi-sovereign  borrowers  in 
Kazakhstan. 

                                                

payment. Further, the preliminary loans will be converted to standard housing loans priced at  3.5%–5% once the 
mortgagor has accumulated sufficient savings. 

34 HCSBK will provide an option for prospective women borrowers who do not fully meet the 55% monthly installment-
to-monthly  income  ratio  by  allowing  the  addition  of  a co-borrower.  This  measure  will  expand  the outreach of  the 
program without compromising its financial soundness. Co-borrowers will have joint responsibility for the fulfillment 
of obligations under the mortgage contract. At the same time, the ownership of the housing unit will remain with the 
woman borrower. 

35 A housing unit can be a house or an apartment in a single-story or multistory building that provides living space for

occupants making up a single household. 

Diagnostic. Washington, DC. 

37 54% of HCSBK’s borrowers are in the low-income segment with a monthly household income of less than T200,000. 
38 On 28 December 2018, HCSBK placed bonds for T57.7 billion through the Astana International Financial Center in 
Nur-Sultan. The maturity date of these bonds is 28 December 2033 and the coupon rate is 9.6% per annum, paid 
semiannually. However, these bonds did not really represent market-based fund-raising efforts, as they were fully 
placed with HCSBK’s parent company, Baiterek. 

 (iv) 

(v) 

The accompanying TA will strengthen the operational capacity, quality, and reach 
of HCSBK in relation to the low- to middle-income female population in Kazakhstan. 
Financial inclusion is closely correlated with reduced poverty, and HCSBK plays a 
unique role in the banking system in Kazakhstan by promoting financial inclusion 
in the housing finance sector among rural low-income female populations that no 
other bank or nonbank financial institution can match. 
ADB played a key role in the project design. In April 2017, ADB identified HCSBK 
as a potential partner for expanding access to finance for women and entered into 
initial  discussions  with  the  bank  to  address  its  funding  shortage  for  preliminary 
loans. After consulting with HCSBK and the government, ADB prepared a detailed 
feasibility  study  on  the  concept  and  structure  of  possible  ADB  assistance  and 
identified the need for TA support. This analytical work has led HCSBK and the 
Government of Kazakhstan to request a sovereign loan from ADB and serves as 
the foundation for the project. 

Summary Financing Plan 

 
D. 
 
21. 
HCSBK has requested a regular loan of up to T38,000,000,000 ($100 million equivalent) 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. The loan, to be guaranteed by 
the Republic of Kazakhstan, will have (i) a term of up to 11 years, (ii) an interest rate equal to the 
sum of ADB’s cost of funding and the contractual spread for sovereign guaranteed loans, (iii) a 
commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  year  on  the  undisbursed  loan  amount,  and  (iv)  such  other 
terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and guarantee agreements. Subject to market 
conditions, ADB will provide local currency financing to fund the loan by issuing disbursement-
linked  bullet  bonds  of  up  to  10-year  maturity,  not  exceeding  the  final  loan  maturity  of  31 
December 2030. Otherwise, ADB will also be able to provide financing in United States dollars. 
The  loan  is  expected  to  be  disbursed  in  two  tranches,  each  of  $20  million  minimum  in  tenge 
equivalent with a bullet repayment structure. This will provide HCSBK with a more stable source 
of funding as it will match the ADB bond issuance in maturity. This structure would be a new and 
innovative  feature  for  an  ADB  public  sector  loan.  No  maturity  premium  is  payable  to  ADB 
because  the  average  loan  maturity  will  not  exceed  13  years.  Based  on  the  requirement  that 
female sub-borrowers will contribute either 15% or 20% (depending on the income level) of the 
individual housing unit cost in the form of equity, the contribution of the mortgagors amounts to 
a total of $24 million.

Procurement  of  goods,  works,  and non-consultancy  services  will  follow  the  ADB 
Procurement Policy and the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, 
as amended from time to time). Procurement will be undertaken by the individual 
beneficiary; fitness for purpose can be achieved by using established private sector 
and commercial practices. 
Retroactive financing will be allowed for up to 20% of the loan amount for eligible 
mortgage  subloans,  incurred  prior  to  loan  effectiveness  but  no  earlier  than  12 
months before the signing of the loan agreement. 
The loan proceeds will be disbursed following ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and detailed arrangements agreed between 
the government and ADB. The ADB loan will be disbursed in two tranches, each of 
$20 million minimum, in tenge equivalent during the implementation period, which 
have to be liquidated within 12 months from the date of receipt of funds. ADB will 
disburse these advances to a dedicated HCSBK bank account.

III. 

ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
The ADB loan will be accompanied by a $620,000 transaction TA funded on a grant basis 
23. 
by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  resources).40 The  TA  will  provide 
capacity  building  services  primarily  involving the following  actions: (i)  improve financial  literacy 
among potential women borrowers in Kazakhstan, (ii) raise awareness for gender-related lending 
aspects in HCSBK’s operations by hiring and training employees to become experts in gender 
related  financing  aspects  in  its  head  office  and  some  of  its  larger  branches,  (iii)  assist  in  the 
implementation  of  a  comprehensive  GAP  in  HCSBK, 41 and  (iv)  enhance  HCSBK’s  customer 
targeting  by  designing  lending  programs  and  products  specific  to  women.  ADB  will  engage 
consultants  in  accordance  with  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to 
time)  and  the  associated  staff  instructions.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in 
accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 

 
A. 

Economic and Financial Viability 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

24. 
HCSBK’s housing savings model presents a viable model to address higher-risk market 
segments as demonstrated by the bank’s low rate of NPLs compared with its peers (i.e., 0.2% 
versus a market average of 7.4% in 2018 in the mortgage sector).42 HCSBK’s preliminary lending 
product is well suited to the lending profile of lower-income earners with less access to collateral, 
                                                
40 The Government of Kazakhstan has contributed $120,000 to ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund in part to 

41 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
42 The  average  monthly  income  of  women  borrowers  financed  by  HCSBK  under  the  existing  government  housing 

finance the transaction TA. 

program is T170,000. 

 

 10 

 

but this product requires diversification of the bank’s funding base to expand its product offering 
and developmental impact.43 The ADB funding will provide HCSBK with the liquidity required to 
develop a new product line (under the preliminary lending segment) targeting underserved women 
borrowers,  who  face  higher  requirements  (on  average)  for  obtaining  mortgage  loans. 44 The 
project will thereby help the bank to adjust its operating model and help it prepare for its eventual 
transition to commercial financing. Such a transition will enhance the sustainability of its housing 
finance business. 
 
The financial viability derives from HCSBK’s strong financial performance and profitable 
25. 
operations.  From  2015  to  2018,  HCSBK  experienced  strong  organic  growth  in  assets,  loans, 
deposits, and equity, with compound annual growth rates of 28% in 2015, 34% in 2016, 30% in 
2017, and 23% in 2018. It also has high profitability, with a return on equity of 15.0% and a return 
on assets of 3.0% as of the end of 2018. HCSBK has good portfolio quality, with a 90 days overdue 
ratio  of  less  than  1%,  because  of  the  following  factors:  (i)  adequate  policies,  procedures,  and 
controls in relation to loan portfolio management, including protocols on instances of default; (ii) 
a good management information system that promptly provides information regarding the status 
of  lending  operations  and  the  financial  performance  of  the  bank;  (iii)  good  payment  discipline 
among  borrowers  given  the  savings  accumulation-based  business  model;  and  (iv)  a  prudent 
collateral policy with 90% of the loan portfolio having a loan-to-value (LTV) ratio of not more than 
75% (36% of loans outstanding have a LTV ratio of less than 50%). In addition to these factors, 
the timely payment of mortgage amortizations is considered a top priority  for any home owner 
given the motivation of a person to eventually own their housing unit. Likewise, mortgagors have 
much more to lose in case of a default considering the collateral (housing unit and savings) and 
the low LTV ratio. HCSBK has sufficient liquidity given its long-term deposit base and low volatility 
brought by the peculiarity of the business model, as well as an ample capital buffer. 
 
26. 
Per statistics from the National Bank of Kazakhstan as of the end of 2018, of the 28 banks 
regulated and supervised by the national bank, HCSBK was ranked 9th in terms of assets (T998 
billion) and deposits (T665 billion), 8th in terms of loan portfolio size (T664 billion), 10th in terms 
of interest spread (5.3%), 13th in terms of net interest margin (5.9%), 9th in terms of capital (with 
a capital adequacy ratio of 54.6%), 4th in terms of liquidity (with a liquidity coefficient of 5.0), and 
1st in terms of having the lowest 90 days overdue loan ratio (0.18% compared with the industry 
average of 7.38%).45 The bank’s good industry rankings are further corroborated by its rating from 
Moody’s Investors Service of Baa3 stable, similar with that of its parent, National Management 
Holding Baiterek JSC, and the sovereign rating of Kazakhstan. 
 
B. 

Sustainability 

27. 
The ADB project is sustainable, as it will expand the number of women in Kazakhstan with 
lower to middle-income levels  who become homeowners through the acquisition of residential 
properties by accessing mortgage finance on reasonable,  predictable, and transparent lending 
terms. The intervention will also reduce HCSBK’s overreliance on government funding and will 
therefore contribute to fiscal sustainability. Finally, the TA attached to the project will demonstrate 
to HCSBK (and other banks in Kazakhstan) that women represent a promising and creditworthy 
borrower segment that can be targeted through tailor-made financial instruments and programs. 
 
                                                
43 The law governing HCSBK prohibits the use of its deposit funds to finance its preliminary lending business, which 

carries more risk. To date, the bank has relied on government funding to expand this business line. 

44 These higher requirements are because of a significant gender pay gap of 69% and the higher proportion of women 

relying on self-employment (particularly in rural areas). 

45  PWC. 2019. HCSBK JSC Financial Statements and Independent Auditor’s Report. (as of 31 December 2018). 

 11 

Governance 

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

C. 
 
28. 
The overall integrity risk is low and the assessed pre-mitigation financial management risk 
is  moderate  mainly  because  the  bank  has  extensive  experience  in  housing  finance  and  has 
successfully  implemented  many  government  housing  programs.  Integrity  due  diligence  was 
conducted.  No  significant  integrity  risks  were  identified.  HCSBK’s  capabilities  are  considered 
adequate.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and 
discussed with the government and HCSBK. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 38).  
 
D. 
 
The  project  is  anticipated  to  have  a  strong  development  impact  in  supporting  broader 
29. 
poverty  reduction  and  welfare  objectives  prioritized  by  the  government.  Homeownership 
complements  the  country’s  welfare  system  by  strengthening  household  security  and  financial 
stability.  Further,  it  eases  access  to  credit,  given  that  real  estate  remains  a  preferred  type  of 
collateral  in  banking  sector  lending.  Lastly,  housing  standards  have  a  direct  impact  on  human 
welfare and help attain better health and education outcomes for occupants. It is also shown to 
enhance maintenance of properties to a higher standard. The GAP describes the steps that will 
be  taken  under  the  project  to  ensure  that  it  fosters  women’s  economic  empowerment  and 
supports  gender  equity  objectives  as  described  in  the  design  and  monitoring  framework 
(Appendix 1). 
 
E. 
 
30. 
The project is categorized FI-C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous 
peoples.  Given  the  nature  of  the  intervention,  the  project  will  have  minimal  or  no  adverse 
environmental  impacts  and  no  impacts  on  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples. 
HCSBK’s loans will not finance real estate development or mass housing construction, but will be 
used  to  provide  residential  mortgage  loans  to  women  borrowers  to  purchase  existing  or 
constructed residential housing units that meet standard requirements and/or to make renovations 
to  such  housing  units.  ADB  has  assessed  the  borrower’s    commitment  and  capacity  for 
environmental and social management. HCSBK has adequate staff capacity to effectively carry 
out the assessment and oversight of the progress of the environmental (including climate change) 
and  social  risks  screening  and  monitoring.  HCSBK  will  (i)  apply  ADB's  prohibited  investment 
activities  list;  (ii)  exclude  funding  by  ADB  of  activities  falling  under  categories  A  and  B  for 
environment and social safeguard impacts; (iii) ensure that investments using ADB funds comply 
with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  abide  by  applicable  national  laws  and 
regulations,  including  labor  laws,  pursuant  to  ADB’s  Social  Protection  Strategy;  and  (iv)  take 
measures to comply with internationally recognized core labor standards. HCSBK will confirm this 
in its periodic reports to ADB and does not need to apply any other specific safeguard or social 
requirements.46 
 
F. 

Summary of Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan 

Safeguards 

31. 
Significant  risks  and  mitigating  measures  are  summarized  in  Table  3  and  described  in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.47 Some significant risks are related to 

                                                
46 Summary  Poverty  Reduction  and  Social  Strategy,  and  Safeguards  and  Social  Dimensions  Summary  (accessible 

from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2.) 

47 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 the volatile economic operating environment and can only be partly mitigated through the project 
as described. However, ADB’s position is protected by the strong credit of the sovereign, which 
guarantees  the  loan.  The  project  is  categorized  low  risk  because  (i)  the  size  of  the  ADB  loan 
amount does not exceed $200 million; (ii) ADB has relevant experience in the banking sector as 
it  has  been  lending  to  various  banks  in  Kazakhstan  in  2011-2018  (iii)  HCSBK  has  adequate 
mechanisms  to  administer  and  monitor  the  disbursement  of  the  mortgage  loans  to  women 
borrowers;  (iv)  HCSBK  has  extensive  experience  in  housing  finance  in  Kazakhstan;  and  (v) 
HCSBK has substantial experience in implementing this type of intervention.48

V. 

ASSURANCES 

 
32. 
The government and HCSBK have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. The government and HCSBK have agreed with ADB on certain 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the draft loan  and guarantee agreements. 
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

33. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of  up  to 
T38,000,000,000 to Housing Construction Savings Bank of Kazakhstan, to be guaranteed by the 
Republic  of  Kazakhstan,  for  the  Promoting  Gender  Equality  in  Housing  Finance  Project,  from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with an annual interest rate equal to the sum 
of ADB’s cost of tenge funding and the contractual spread for sovereign guaranteed loans; for a 
term of up to 11 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft loan and guarantee agreements presented to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
Output 1: Long-term affordable mortgage financing for eligible women borrowers made available. 
1.1 ADB provides up to $100 million for qualified subloans issued by HCSBK (2019: $0 million; 2020: $30 million; 
and 2021: $70 million) 
Output 2: Greater accessibility to HCSBK’s lending products for eligible women borrowers. 
2.1 HCSBK develops at least one lending product exclusively targeted at women borrowers (by March 2020) 
2.2 HCSBK adopts a gender policy (by March 2020) 
2.3 HCSBK conducts at least three nationwide public awareness campaigns on housing finance products for 
women (by March 2020) 
Output 3: Gender inclusiveness of the banking sector’s housing finance assessed. 
3.1 HCSBK’s financial skills training program focused on women becomes fully operational (by December 2020) 
 
Inputs 
ADB: $100 million equivalent (loan), $500,000 Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources) 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Contribution of $120,000 to the technical assistance funded by the Government of Kazakhstan from its Knowledge 
and Experience Exchange Programb with ADB 

ADB = Asian Development Bank, HCSBK = Housing Construction Savings Bank of Kazakhstan.

and women borrowers combined), projected based on recent historical performance (2016–2018).
